thread.title: UCLA will try to end skid vs. Stanford
thread.title_full: UCLA will try to end skid vs. Stanford | The Seattle Times

author: Seattle Times staff
title: UCLA will try to end skid vs. Stanford
text:
STANFORD, Calif. — For all of UCLA’s success under coach Jim Mora, there’s one thing he hasn’t been able to change: Stanford’s dominance in this California rivalry.
With seven straight wins, including in the 2012 Pac-12 title game and a late-season game last year that cost the Bruins a shot at the South Division title, Stanford has had UCLA’s number since shortly after Jim Harbaugh revived the program.
Not that that matters to either team heading into Thursday night’s game between No. 18 UCLA (4-1, 1-1) and No. 15 Stanford (4-1, 3-0).
“We’re 0-0 against them this year,” Cardinal defensive back Kodi Whitfield said.
Most Read Stories Seattle Seahawks release WR B.J. Daniels, RB Rod Smith Ana Mari Cauce new UW president; popular on, off campus USC fires head coach Steve Sarkisian, former UW Huskies coach Seattle council candidate alleges shakedown by developer Truck wrecks cause huge I-5 backups during morning rush Unlimited Digital Access. $1 for 4 weeks. Mora, who has lost all four meetings against the Cardinal, sees no need to address the recent struggles with his players.
“Every year is a different deal,” he said. “If you dwell on the past, whether it’s positive past or not-so-positive past, it’s the wrong thing to do.”
Fired USC coach Steve Sarkisian said on Twitter he is going through “a very difficult time” right now.
In his first public comments since his dismissal, Sarkisian wished the Trojans good luck against Notre Dame on Saturday and said he will be cheering for them.
The former Washington coach also expressed his gratitude for the support he had received.
After practice, USC quarterback Cody Kessler voiced his support for his former coach.
“Obviously, (Sarkisian is) dealing with some tough stuff right now, but I wish him nothing but the best. I really do,” Kessler told ESPN.com . “There’s no hard feelings from me. … 
“I know this team doesn’t, either. The first thing this team wants is for him to get better. We’re still going to support him.”
Notes • Florida freshman defensive back Deiondre Porter was suspended indefinitely after his arrest for allegedly firing a gun in the direction of his pregnant girlfriend. Porter was being held on a $160,000 bond in jail.
• Portland State’s Bruce Barnum , a first-time head coach whose Vikings opened the season with their first victory over a Pac-12 team, winning at Washington State, was given a five-year contract, the school announced. Portland State has gone on to compile a 4-1 record.
Seattle Times staff
